story:
Once upon a time, in the beautiful island nation of Sri Lanka, there was a little girl named Sariya. Sariya lived in a small village near the jungle with her mother, father, and younger brother. She was a curious and adventurous girl who loved exploring the world around her.

One day, Sariya's mother told her a story about a magical bird that lived in the jungle. This bird, called the "Ran Thorawu," was said to have the most beautiful singing voice in all the land. It was also believed to have magical powers, and whoever heard its song would be filled with happiness and good fortune.

Sariya was fascinated by this story and begged her parents to take her into the jungle to find the Ran Thorawu. Her father, who was a wise and experienced hunter, warned her that the jungle was a dangerous place and that they must be very careful. But he also knew how much his daughter longed to see the magical bird, so he agreed to take her on a journey to find it.

The next day, Sariya, her father, and her brother set out early in the morning, armed with food, water, and a map that her father had drawn. They walked for hours, deeper and deeper into the jungle. The trees grew taller and the air grew thicker, but Sariya was not afraid. She felt a thrill of excitement as she imagined hearing the Ran Thorawu's magical song.

As they walked, they came across many wonders of the jungle: brightly colored butterflies, monkeys swinging from tree to tree, and even a family of elephants bathing in a stream. But there was no sign of the Ran Thorawu.

Just as they were about to give up, they heard a beautiful song, so sweet and pure that it seemed to come from the heavens themselves. Sariya's heart leapt with joy as she realized that they had found the Ran Thorawu!

The bird was even more beautiful than Sariya had imagined. Its feathers were a brilliant shade of blue, and its eyes sparkled like diamonds. And its song was truly magical, filling Sariya and her family with a sense of peace and happiness that they had never known before.

As they listened to the Ran Thorawu's song, they felt as if they were lifted up and carried away to a place of wonder and enchantment. And when the bird finally fell silent, they knew that they had been blessed with a gift that would stay with them forever.

From that day on, Sariya and her family spoke of the Ran Thorawu and its magical song with a sense of awe and reverence. And Sariya never forgot the lesson that her father had taught her: that the greatest adventures are those that take us deep into the wonders of the natural world, and that sometimes, the most magical things of all are those that are hidden in plain sight.

And with that, my dear daughter, it is time for you to close your eyes and drift off to sleep, filled with dreams of magic and wonder. Goodnight.
